This episode was about the flemen response but didn't really explain what a flehmen response actually is.

Hate to say it hank but you missed a gold mine of animal weirdness with this one.

First of all. What is the flehmen response? Yes, when those animals make those faces, those are flehmen response. But that isn't just what they are.

What they are, are complex actions taken without direct intervention by the brain and which must be completed in sequence once they begin and which most importantly are not learned actions. They are built in, through evolution using various reflex responses to craft a choreographed action.

The reason those vasonasal organs require flehmen responses to function is touched on - they are not a passive sensory organ, it needs to be actively engaged. But the process that allow that engagement are precise and intricate and complex. Little muscles twitching in a very specific order and intensity that once it begins must function to completion.

Why the pedantry? Why go to such lengths explaining basically exactly what hank did only to say that hank missed the bigger picture?

Because vasonasal sniffing is not the only flehmen response. It's not even the most interesting one. The most interesting one i know about is what happens when you try to take an egg out of a swan's nest. If a swan (it may be limited to certain species of swan) sees an egg outside her nest, the swan will instinctively extend it's neck, hook it's beak around the edge of the egg and do a sort of complex wiggle of its head to shimmy the egg back into its nest.

It looks like a regular action until you do a few more things and observe. First of all, the swan will do this with any rough analog for an egg. Anything small round and whiteish will send the swan into a series of movements which will push the "egg" back into the nest. It's instinctual. Mother swans don't need to be taught this trick. They just see an egg and their head moves reflexively.

The other thing you can do which will show the true nature of the flehmen response is when you take the egg away after you've triggered the reflex. The swan will continue to make the complex series of head movements, shimmying a non existent egg up into its nest.

It can't stop itself. Once it starts it can't stop. It doesn't need to learn what is actually a complex sequence of actions taken in a specific order. And yes the scientist (i think he was named flehmen) discovered these sorts of animal reflexes trying to explain that absolutely ridiculous horse facial expression.

Actually human adults do have a vomeronasal organ its just that the organ is not connected to any nerve endings and (at least in most humans) seems to be very small and non-functional now.  Some people seem to have lost them altogether and certain key genes which have analogues in other animals and are known to affect the vomeronasal organ seem to have become non-coding in humans.

Came here wondering why my cats look so done with everything, came back knowing the explanation for a different face

Why Is Your Cat So Disgusted With You?

You don't hunt properly.
You don't clean their litter box often enough.
You don't give them enough food, and when they want it.
You don't pay enough attention to them, and don't preen them enough. (i.e. brushing, petting, etc.)
Their daily cereal isn't as tasty as they treats they're only supposed to get once per day.
The new fabric softener has a scent that hurts the kitty's sensibilities.

Oh sure, on the outside they're affectionate and loving, but on the inside, they're ready to eat you if the need arises... :)

I don't understand this idea that cats are smug, superior-minded creatures. The last time I lived with cats they immediately perked up and wanted to be around me whenever I was gone
for a while. One would always follow me when I was watering the garden and harvesting, and just seemed fascinated with everything I did. Another seemed very independent during the day
but at night just wanted to snuggle. The third was always happy to snuggle but was also a fierce hunter, and brought us "gifts" in the form of small animals.

I know some people theorize cats feel sorry for us because we're such terrible hunters, but they still beg us for food and treats when they want it. I feel it's more likely when cats and other animals offer us food they're doing it as thanks for always providing for them. For an animal the best way to show love would probably be the gift of food.
